content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" was established to address the significant increase in tuition at public colleges and universities, which outpaced the rise in household income and consumer goods costs. Concerns about college affordability were at a 30-year high, making college education one of the most expensive investments for American families. The "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" is established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" to address the rising tuition costs at public colleges and universities. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The members will elect a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority required for a quorum. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. A majority of the members constitute a quorum for business transactions. Appointments must be made within 30 days, with provisions for appointments if not made within the specified timeframe. Members of the Commission shall be entitled to one vote each, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission members are entitled to one vote each, vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members receive no additional pay, but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The initial meeting must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission is responsible for specific functions. The Commission is tasked with studying and making recommendations on various aspects related to college tuition, including the increase in tuition compared to other commodities, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs and staffing, faculty workload and remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, and tenure practices. The curr_chunk discusses trends in faculty workload, remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, classroom hours, tenure practices, construction and renovation of facilities, modernization for new technologies, financial aid impact on tuition increases, and demographics of aid recipients. The curr_chunk focuses on the impact of institutional financial aid and tuition discounting on tuition increases, including aid distribution to students with limited need, the use of Federal financial aid to offset increases, the influence of laws and regulations on tuition, and the need for better data distribution on tuition trends and operating costs of colleges and universities. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for reducing mandates contributing to tuition increases, timely data distribution on tuition trends, the impact of student financial aid programs on tuition, and other relevant topics determined by the Commission. The final report will contain detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations to be submitted to the President and Congress within 120 days of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members present and voting. The Commission has powers to submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for action to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission may require information from federal agencies as needed. Federal agencies must provide information to the Commission upon request, subject to legal limitations. The Commission can also request facilities, services, and personnel from federal agencies when necessary. The Commission can request facilities, services, and personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. Additionally, the Commission may use the United States mails and enter into contracts for research or surveys as needed. The Commission can enter into contracts with various entities for research purposes and the Chairperson has the authority to appoint staff members. The Commission has the power to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is authorized to appropriate up to $650,000 for its expenses, with funds remaining available until expended or one year after its termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report as required.
